thread.title: Hawaii Signals It Will Take Trump To Court Over Immigration Order
thread.title_full: Hawaii Signals It Will Take Trump To Court Over Immigration Order

author: Jack Davis
title: Hawaii Signals It Will Take Trump To Court Over Immigration Order
text:
Hawaii Signals It Will Take Trump To Court Over Immigration Order "... this isn't about protecting us from bad guys ..." by Jack Davis March 8, 2017 at 7:43am Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
President Donald Trump’s revised immigration order will be facing a court challenge from the state of Hawaii , whose attorney general has dubbed the order “Muslim ban 2.0.” 
Court documents filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court indicate that the state will seek a temporary restraining order over Trump’s new order, which replaces one issued Jan. 27 but which was only in effect a few days before being put in abeyance by the courts. 
“We welcome those who come to our country wishing to contribute and share in our nation’s prosperity and wellbeing, but we cannot allow our immigration system to become a vehicle for admitting people who intend to do us harm,” White House press secretary Sean Spicer said Monday in announcing that Trump had signed the new order. Advertisement - story continues below 
“It is the president’s solemn duty to protect the American people, and president Trump has taken an important step in securing our borders through this order,” he added. 
The documents filed Tuesday do not disclose the legal argument against Trump’s order. 
“This new executive order is nothing more than Muslim Ban 2.0. Under the pretense of national security, it still targets immigrants and refugees,” said Hawaii Attorney General Douglas C. Chin, a Democrat. “It leaves the door open for even further restrictions.” Advertisement - story continues below 
Neal Katyal, an attorney working with the state, implied Trump’s words would be used against him, noting that in the first ban, Trump said announcing the ban in advance of its effective date would limit its effectiveness. 
“Of course, this time not only did he take a week but he took 10 days,” Katyal said. “So I really think it just underscores the lack of national security justification here — this isn’t about protecting us from bad guys rushing into the country, this is about politics.” 
Alan Dershowitz , a Harvard law professor emeritus, told Fox Business Network, however, that the new order may be hard to beat. 
“From a view of constitutionality, they have dotted their I’s, they crossed their T’s (and) they will probably prevail in court proceedings.” Advertisement - story continues below
